head.title: Slain Woman's Sister Seeks Custody Accord

identified-content.classifier: Top/News/U.S./U.S. States, Territories and Possessions/New Jersey

hedline.hl1: Slain Woman's Sister Seeks Custody Accord

block.p: The sister of a New Jersey woman whose husband is charged in her murder is hoping to win custody of the couple's two children without resorting to Jordanian courts, her Jordanian lawyer said today.

The lawyer said Muhammad Ismail Abequa, who is being held on charges of first-degree murder and kidnapping, can resolve a dispute by signing over custody to his wife's family. But members of Mr. Abequa's family have insisted they want the children raised in Jordan.
The sister of a New Jersey woman whose husband is charged in her murder is hoping to win custody of the couple's two children without resorting to Jordanian courts, her Jordanian lawyer said today.

The lawyer said Muhammad Ismail Abequa, who is being held on charges of first-degree murder and kidnapping, can resolve a dispute by signing over custody to his wife's family. But members of Mr. Abequa's family have insisted they want the children raised in Jordan.
Mr. Abequa, a naturalized American born in Jordan, has confessed to strangling his wife, Nihal, and fleeing here with their children, Lisa, 6, and Sami, 3.
Nihal Abequa's sister, Nesime Dokur, arrived in Jordan with two American lawyers on Monday seeking to return to the United States with the children.
She appointed two Jordanian lawyers, Yacoub Far and Abdullah al-Khalil, to represent her and her mother, Meryem Gussal, who have been named by a New Jersey judge as the children's legal guardians.
Jordanian officials have said the courts are likely to rule in favor of Nihal Abequa's family. But Ms. Dokur's lawyers are hoping to avoid a protracted custody battle by solving the case amicably.
The children are staying with Mr. Abequa's mother on the outskirts of Amman.
The United States Ambassador, Wesley W. Egan, discussed the case this week with Jordan's Minister of Justice, Hisham Etall. He said an administrative solution was possible.
Mr. Egan said he would also continue to work for Mr. Abequa's extradition to the United States.
